isis.stitle: DT/DTI-466 A and B Series DT/DTI/DTA-466 C Diesel Engine Diagnostics (1993) - ENGINE DIAGNOSTIC TEST PROCEDURES - DT/DTI/DTA - 466 C SERIES DIESEL ENGINES - SHUTOFF CABLE/ELECTRIC SHUTOFF DT/DTI/DTA-466 C Engines (With Robert Bosch "MW" or "A" Fuel Injection Pump) - II. INTERNALLY SWITCHED ELECTRIC SHUTOFF (AUTOMATIC SHUTOFF) - PRIOR TO 1989 M0DEL YEAR

svcproc.title: II. INTERNALLY SWITCHED ELECTRIC SHUTOFF (AUTOMATIC SHUTOFF) - PRIOR TO 1989 M0DEL YEAR

para.emph: PROBLEM: ENGINE WILL CRANK, BUT WILL NOT START.

caution.para: PLACE THE TRANSMISSION IN NEUTRAL WITH THE PARKING BRAKE ENGAGED.

important.para: VERIFY THE ELECTRIC SHUTOFF IS INOPERABLE AS FOLLOWS: VISUALLY OBSERVE SHUTOFF LEVER (1, F1GURE 6.21) AND TURN THE IGNITION SWITCH TO THE "IGNITION" POSITION. THE SHUTOFF LEVER SHOULD ROTATE COUNTERCLOCKWISE (CCW) AS THE SOLENOID PLUNGER "PULLS IN". IF THIS DOES NOT OCCUR, TURN THE IGNITION SWITCH TO THE "START" POSITION. IF THE PLUNGER STILL HAS NOT "PULLED IN", DETERMINE THE CAUSE AND CORRECT AS FOLLOWS:

step1.para: Fuse - Inspect the electric shutoff fuse. If burned out, replace.
12 Volt Supply - Check for 12 volts between the positive and negative terminals of the solenoid mating connector with the fuse in place.

svcproc.para: Turn the key switch to the "ignition" position. The minimum voltage required for the solenoid topull in is 9 volts.

caution.para: DO NOT "JUMP" OR BYPASS THE FUSE. DO NOT ALLOW VOLTMETER NEGATIVE TEST LEAD TO SHORT BETWEEN THE (-) NEGATIVE AND SMALLER "AUX" TERMINAL ON THE SOLENOID. IF THIS OCCURS, FUSE OR SOLENOID FAILURE MAY RESULT. (SEE FIGURE 6.21 FOR TERMINAL LOCATION).

note.para: "AUX" terminal is present only on early model solenoids used on "MW" pumps.

important.para: IF VOLTAGE AVAILABLE TO SOLENOID IS UNDER 12 V DC, CHECK BATTERY CONDITION, WIRING AND CONNECTIONS, IGNITION SWITCH AND ELECTRIC SHUTOFF RELAY (IF APPLICABLE). REPLACE ANY STAR TYPE LOCKWASHERS FOUND ON SOLENOID TERMINALS WITH SPLIT TYPE LOCKWASHERS.

step1.para: Rubber Boot - The rubber boot seals the core from dirt and moisture.

svcproc.para: Verify that the boot is firmly attached to the sole noid body.
Replace any solenoid which has a torn boot.

note.para: The boot should be free of paint. Paint will cause the boot to become soft and catch between the spring and plunger. This will prevent the plunger from seating properly. The boot should also have a small breather hole in the second pleat from the base of the solenoid.

svcproc.para: Inspect for evidence of dust, dirt, brass powder, or blackened deposits on the plunger or in the solenoid core.

note.para: If evidence of a worn solenoid is found, as described above, solenoid condition is marginal and may not "pull in" quickly or consistently.

step1.para:
Measure resistance (ohms) across the positive and negative terminals of the solenoid as follows: (Refer to the Internal Switch Description and Figure 6.23)
.

svcproc.para: Be sure the ignition switch is off. Disconnect the power supply to the solenoid. Remove the plunger and connect an ohm meter to the (+) positive and (-) negative terminals (Figure 6.22).
With the plunger removed, .16 to .23 ohms resistance should be observed.
Using a wooden dowel rod, depress the switch button in the bottom of the solenoid core. (This simulates the plunger in position). 11.6 to 16.5 ohms resistance should be observed.

figure.caption: Figure 6.21 Internally Switched Electric Shutoff Solenoid (Installed View on Robert Bosch "MW" Pump)

calloutgroup.callout1: 6. Rubber Boot (Surrounds Return Spring and Plunger)

para.emph: *-"AUX" terminal is present only on early model solenoids.

svcproc.para: The solenoid contains a built-in switch that is activated when the plunger nears the bottom of its stroke. The switch button extends from the bottom of the solenoid end cap into the core.

note.para: If Solenoid replacement is required, refer to the DT/DTA-466 Diesel Engine Service Manual [CGES-415-*] for removal, installation and adjustment procedures.

figure.caption: Figure 6.23 Internal Switch Button [Located in the Bottom of the Solenoid Core]
